dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: Althorp Estate, 1774 Two servants knock in four flag posts, with fifty paces i between. They are marking out a race track of some kind. We’re on the back lawn of a beautiful country house. Off the distance are fields filled with sheep, long grass and trees. It’s a perfect summer’s day with birds singing and gentle breeze rustling in leaves. Six ARISTOCRATIC YOUNG MEN stand in a group on the field. They are preparing for a running race: taking their jacke off and laying them down, then rolling up their sleeves. On the lawn, a similar sized group of ARISTOCRATIC YOUNG WOMEN stand across from them. Behind is a tent and a tabl with the remains of an outdoor picnic. To one side of the women a young, beautiful and content GEORGIANA approaches with a hat. Inside are folded up pieces of paper which she mixes around. She offers the ha to the women and they each pick a piece of paper. One aft another they read out the names of the men opposite who look over and smile. GEORGIANA is left with the last name and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (Loudly) You'd better not let me down, Charles Grey. I’ve got twenty guineas riding on you. A young man, CHARLES GREY looks back. He is quick to repl

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Only twenty? I’d double that if I were you. GEORGIANA smiles, while the look on Grey’s face suggests that he’s taking this very seriously. He joins the other men in the starting line up, who also seem pretty intent winning.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Are you ready gentlemen? Twice around the track. On my count, three...two...one...go! GEORGIANA drops a handkerchief. The men immediately sprin out across the park. The women start to cheer. GEORGIANA shouts the loudest, then starts to jump up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Grey, come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In CLOSE UP, a quill pen dips into an ink well and starts to write on a virgin piece of white paper, ‘The Fourteent Day of May, Seventeen Hundred and Seventy Four...’ HEATON, a solicitor, is at a table writing this document, his ink pen scraping against the paper. Around him, the room has the atmosphere of a serious occasion: still and dark although the sun shines brightly outside and the voices of the women - especially GEORGIANA - bleed throug The DUKE, HEATON’s employer, is standing at the library window, looking into the garden at GEORGIANA cheering on the young men. The scene is distorted through the wavy glass window pane: a beautiful and mildly surreal image. LADY SPENCER is seated behind the DUKE, perched on the ed of a large sofa, with LORD SPENCER behind her. She tries ignore the muted screams of her daughter in the backgroun

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: (Cautiously) I trust your Grace still finds Georgiana an attractive girl? The DUKE turns and we now see his face properly. He is handsome, older than GEORGIANA, and has a rakish twinkle his eye. He looks at LADY SPENCER enigmatically.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Of course, Lady Spencer. Another of GEORGIANA’s shouts audibly registers. LADY SPENCER starts to pour tea from a silver Samovar in front of her in an effort to drown out the noise.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: She is well-bred and devoted to her duties. She speaks French, Latin and Italian, and is fully versed in horsemanship and dancing...

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Yes, I am aware of all that. She is a credit to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --.-I can't think of anything in her that would stand in the way of a singularly happy marriage - The DUKE turns for a brief moment and smiles inscrutably LADY SPENCER. HEATON cuts to the chase.

dialogues.speaker: HEATON
dialogues.text: These are not the issues that burden the Duke, Lady Spencer. It is His Grace’s duty to produce an heir. On the other hand, your daughter may expect a handsome reward when that occurs -—

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Heaton.

dialogues.speaker: BURLEIGH
dialogues.text: (resuming his writing) Your Grace ... The DUKE remains looking out of the window, not so much o of interest in GEORGIANA, but rather because he finds the pre-nuptial proceedings uncomfortable. LADY SPENCER throw a brief glance at LORD SPENCER, who seems disinclined to discuss these matters. She resolutely turns to the DUKE.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Your Grace can rest assured. The women in our family have never forfeited on that account. LADY SPENCER smiles at her husband who nods back. HEATON looks to the DUKE for confirmation, then decides to addre his comment to no one in particular.

dialogues.speaker: HEATON
dialogues.text: Well with that assurance... HEATON turns the document around toward the others for th to look at. The DUKE smiles at them, then turns and fastidiously removes a spot on the window pane.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: So be it, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are running back. GREY is in the lead.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Come on Grey! GREY puts his head down and accelerates. He wins, totally out of breath and sweating. All the others follow, similarly exhausted and bent over double. GEORGIANA turns to the other women, a book containing all the bets they’ve laid in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Charming smile) I do apologise ladies but it appears my horse has won. The young women smile, and gather around GEORGIANA. GREY approaches from behind, still slightly out of breath, man and athletic. GEORGIANA turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well done Mr Grey. He looks intensely at her, bravely standing much closer than may normally be expected. Some of the young people notice this, and there’s an edge of tension at this risqu behaviour.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: (Plirtatiously) And my reward? GEORGIANA returns the look.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: What would you suggest? The young people - eavesdropping on this conversation - smile and look at each other. GREY is just about to come back with a reply when...

dialogues.speaker: SERVANT
dialogues.text: Your mother wishes to see you Lady Georgiana.  4aAk GEORGIANA curtsies to GREY who bows in return before GEORGIANA runs off. GREY watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ALTHORP. DAY 4aA LADY SPENCER waits inside. GEORGIANA enters.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I must apologize Mama, were we making too much noise?

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Not at all, darling. We have much more important things to talk of. Come here. GEORGIANA waits expectantly for an explanation. LADY SPENCER reveals nothing, holding in her secret, but her excitement can’t help but shine through.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have heard a rumour... LADY SPENCER pauses for dramatic effect.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Yes...?

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: ...that I shall very soon be addressing my daughter as Her Grace, the Duchess of Devonshire. GEORGIANA is taken wholly by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Is it true, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: (Proudly) It is.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: ...the Duke of Devonshire ...

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: I had hoped not to part with you until 18 at the soonest, but with such a fine match it would be selfish of me not to let you go.  4aB

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: He loves me?

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (Excited) I have met him only twice.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: When one truly loves someone, one doesn't have to know them well to be certain, Georgiana. One feels it right away. [Pause] I do believe you will be happy with him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I know I shall, Mama...I know I shall.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. ALTHORP. DAY 4aB GEORGIANA walks out onto the balcony and looks into the garden. The young people are chatting and eating. GREY, however, is to one side, looking out across the fields. GEORGIANA takes a moment to herself. In the last light of day, sun rays illuminate pollen in the air around her. Th camera moves in to a CLOSE UP of her optimistic face.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: OMITTED 4n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP of GEORGIANA’S face, same framing as before, but now heavily made up and in her BRIDAL DRESS. Wedding musi plays as she is walking forward down the aisle, in this relatively small and intimate space. At the far end stand a select group of powerful and important ARISTOCRATS. As GEORGIANA passes LADY SPENCER, her mother looks incredibly proud. When GEORGIANA reaches THE DUKE, he looks composed. She smiles at him. Credits are superimposed throughout this sequence, until the main title appears as GEORGIANA stands at the front:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music stops. The PRIEST steps up to begin the service

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. DUKE’S GILT COACH. LONDON STREET - DAY 9 It’s a wide and busy London street. There are ORDINARY PEOPLE on the side of it, TRAFFIC kicking up dust. It’s a messy mass of noise and smells, smoke and dirt. Through the middle of this comes the DUKE’S GILT COACH followed by two other COACHES, in stark contrast to their surroundings. Heads turn to look at this eighteenth centu motorcade, people wave, children start to run after it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DUKE’S GILT COACH. LONDON STREET - DAY 9A Still in her wedding dress, GEORGIANA sits alongside the DUKE in his CARRIAGE. The DUKE has his curtains closed around him to shield him from public view, although GEORGIANA is staring intently at the PEOPLE outside. There’s an awkward silence. Finally,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: What do they want?

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: To see me. And my new wife, of course.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: It’s a damn nuisance, but you’1l get used to it. GEORGIANA, however, smiles and gives a little wave: she doesn’t mind at all. A bit further down this street the CARRIAGE nears a set o massive gates where a large group of THE GENERAL PUBLIC c be seen waiting and waving outside.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here we are. The carriage begins to turn.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. DEVONSHIRE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The CARRIAGE turns off the street and through the massive gateway. The gates are locked behind them. Inside the huge courtyard Devonshire House is revealed as an oversized, stark and austere building. A wall runs all the way around it, blocking the view and completes the foreboding sense of arriving in a prison. The FOOTMAN ope GEORGIANA’s carriage door. GEORGIANA steps out into this hugely intimidating space. Flags bearing the Duke’s crest blow in the wind, making a tense and aggressive sound. She stops a moment to take it all in. BURLEIGH, the HEAD BUTLER steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: BURLEIGH
dialogues.text: Welcome, Your Grace. BURLEIGH then leads her toward rows of HOUSEHOLD SERVANTS who are formally lined up to greet her. They bow and curt as GEORGIANA walks past.

dialogues.speaker: SERVANT 1
dialogues.text: Your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: SERVANT 2
dialogues.text: Your Grace. GEORGIANA looks up to find the DUKE has disappeared insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA enters a massive marbled ENTRANCE HALL. The DUK stands at the top of the staircase, with his two dogs either side of him.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA stands in front of the DUKE. He takes a pair of scissors and cuts through the stitching of her wedding dress, letting it fall to the floor. She smiles at him, a bit nervous. He proceeds to remove the rest of her underclothes, a pile growing around her ankles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in safe hands. His attempt to reassure her only serves to unnerve GEORGI more. She remains standing and looks up at the ceiling, w the DUKE expertly unlaces her corset.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For the life of me I don't understand why women's attire must be so damned complicated.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I suppose it's just our way of expressing ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: Whatever do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Well, that you have so many ways of expressing yourselves, whereas we must make do with our hats and our dresses, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: Hmmm. The corset falls to the floor. The DUKE then removes GEORGIANA’S chemise. Suddenly, she is completely naked. S sends the DUKE an uneasy look. For a moment he appears to be lost in his thoughts, just staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Is something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: No, not in the least. Go to the bed, please. GEORGIANA goes to the bed. The DUKE starts to undress. Around him the faces of his forefathers bear down from th massive portraits on the walls of his bedroom.  12 13 14 The DUKE, now naked, walks over to the bed and stands before her. The camera is behind the DUKE and focussed on GEORGIANA: having never seen a penis before let alone an erect one, she is intently and nervously staring at his.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Bending down) Kiss me. GEORGIANA finally kisses him, inexpertly. He lies down on of and penetrates her, the look on her face suggesting th is an extremely new and strange experience. The DUKE begi to move rhythmically while GEORGIANA still tries to make sense of the whole thing - all the time watched intensely from the walls by dozens of his male ancestors’ eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA sits looking isolated and lonely in a huge gilt edged blue room. She is trying to read a book but her concentration continues to be interrupted by the presence of MALE FOOTMEN stationed at two of the doors, like sentries. She turns a page and tries to focus but fails. A TALL SERVANT enters. GEORGIANA puts the book down.

dialogues.speaker: HEATON
dialogues.text: Lady Spencer, Your Grace. GEORGIANA looks up, relieved, to see her mother enter. HEATON bows and walks away across the vast space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA sits with LADY SPENCER. They are playing cards with real money laid out in front of them - and talking.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: ...One has to accept one's responsibility, my darling. Certain obligations come with marriage, no matter how burdensome they may seem.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Yes, but when we are together, intimately, I mean, he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know; it can be a bother. However, it is only until you have given him a son. The occasions will then become fewer, and less...determined. Lady Spencer places down a card.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I think it would feel different if he might talk to me every once ina while. It’s not that he’s unkind but he never talks to me.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Well, perhaps you ought to talk less. I fear I may have given you a little too much education. You make tiring conversation and ask questions which a man is disinclined to answer. GEORGIANA looks at her mother in resignation. How can any have too much education?

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Learning these things takes time, too. Marriage is just like languages or music or painting. It requires a long apprenticeship.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Yes. But he is... he is not at all as when I first met him. I thought he would be like Papa. Under his cool reserve I would find a wealth of depth and sentiment. But he doesn’t seem interested in anything. Apart from his dogs.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Try not to be too hard on His Grace, G. He is merely intent on fulfilling his duty. As for talking to him - whatever is there to talk about, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: No, you're right. How foolish of me to think that I should be able to converse with my husband. LADY SPENCER sighs and looks at her spirited daughter.  15

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Georgiana, equip yourself with patience, fortitude and resignation. A boy will come soon enough, then you'll see. GEORGIANA nods. She sends her mother a polite little smil then lays down a winning card and scoops the pile of mone toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great, noisy dinner party. WHIGS in full gala, among which is CHARLES FOX, a stout little man making a speech the grand room. Everybody listens to him. HEATON watches from the side. GEORGIANA is by his side, her attire conspicuously more daring than before. She looks apprehensive: she is the on woman in a room dominated by alcohol and testosterone- fuelled MEN, one of whom is relieving himself into a chamber pot at the side of the room. GEORGIANA, though, pays attention to FOX. The DUKE, at the other end of the table, does not.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: «+-a political party, in my definition, consists of men of honour, entertaining similar principles that may be more successfully pursued by the force of mutual support and, not to forget, the unfailing generosity of his Grace the Duke of Devonshire. Everybody looks to the DUKE, applauding loudly and somewh sycophantically. The DUKE nods cordially.

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So between the persistence of my own humble self... Everybody laughs again, including GEORGIANA, thus betrayi that nobody finds Fox humble. FOX, pleased with the succe of his joke, joins in the laughter.

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I say, between my persistence and the Duke's purse, we must always remember the honourable and principle aims of the Whig party, aims that some consider radical but which, to us, seem simply just and right and sensible. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to bring independence to America. Right to end the slave trade. And sensible to pursue freedom for the common man, so that the blessings of this blessed plot, this England, may be more equally enjoyed - by all of its inhabitants. All these are greeted by ‘hear hears’ from the room, and deep thoughtfulness from GEORGIANA.

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so - having kept everyone from the burgundy long enough - let me propose a toast to our host and benefactor his Grace, the Duke, and his beautiful new Duchess. They all shout "hear, hear", reach for their glasses and toast in the direction of the DUKE. He nods cordially bac FOX sits down at GEORGIANA's side. The murmur of small ta rises as the guests carry on with their eating and drinki A MACARONI on the other side of FOX compliments his speec

dialogues.speaker: MACARONI
dialogues.text: Excellent speech, Mr. Fox, splendid.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: I thank you. However, it is always easy to address a congregation of friends, and even more so when those friends are drunk. The MACARONI and GEORGIANA smile.

dialogues.speaker: MACARONI
dialogues.text: How did the Duchess find Mr. Fox's speech?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I must confess I am not yet at ease with political speeches. Their very form tends to obstruct my view to their actual meaning - if such there be. FOX, expecting inane flattery, is surprised, although favourably impressed by GEORGIANA's candour. The MACARONI not observing that GEORGIANA has earned FOX's undivided attention, proceeds to think that he is still part of the conversation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Ingratiatingly) I myself found it very rousing... FOX ignores him. He knows who he wants to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: In which particular section of the speech did the message elude your Grace?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Well, I have great sympathy with your sentiments in general, but fail fully to comprehend how far we - the Whig party, that is - are fully committed to the concept of freedom.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: We would like to see the vote extended...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: To all men...?

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Heavens no. But certainly to more men. Freedom, in moderation.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: "Freedom in moderation"?

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: (Pleased with himself) Precisely. GEORGIANA nods, then smiles faintly, but mischievously.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I am sure you are full of the best intentions, Mr. Fox, but I dare say I would not spend my vote - assuming I had it - on so vague a statement. Either one is free or one is not. The concept of freedom is an absolute. After all, one cannot be moderately dead, moderately loved, or moderately free. It must always remain a matter of either or. Fox smiles at GEORGIANA in surprise.  16

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Cheeky ) It is no wonder you are having such problems at the ballot box. GEORGIANA smiles, winningly. Fox scrutinizes her face, no a little shocked but clearly impressed. Another well-dressed MAN taps his glass and rises to spea The room falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I think it's appropriate to say a few words... The DUKE seems in no mood for another speech, and resolut gets up and leaves. The entire company, including the MAN about to make a speech, look bewildered at one another. GEORGIANA, too, is surprised and doesn’t really know what she should do, so she stands too and goes after the DUKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DUKE is in the middle of a corridor, where he has sto to talk to a YOUNG MAID. GEORGIANA exits the room behind trying to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Your Grace? The DUKE turns and looks at GEORGIANA. The YOUNG MAID curtsies and exits.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is anything the matter?

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: You just left?

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Well... I had done eating. And those damn speeches bore me to distraction. We have to ban them in the future.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: But you are the Whigs main supporter...  17

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: I have no problem with politics, it’s the rhetoric I can’t stand. The DUKE turns back and continues down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Shall I come with you?

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Not at all, why ever should you? The DUKE turns and leaves. GEORGIANA looks at him, bemuse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conversation has stopped, everyone fearful their benefactor is aggrieved for some reason. The whole table men watch as GEORGIANA sits back down, looking to her for reassurance. She addresses the room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: The Duke is fine. He simply wants to rest a while. People don’t look convinced.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Was it the length of the speech that got the better of the Duke?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (To the room) Certainly not. He enjoyed it immensely and expressed a hope that next time it would be even longer. All the men laugh. Fox sends her a look and raises his gl to her. She smiles back at them all, reaches out for a dr raises it back to FOX and takes a long swig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late night, and all the guests have left. BURLEIGH overse as a team of SERVANTS are clearing up the mess: extinguishing the candles on the huge candelabra, on thei hands and knees scraping food under the table etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA passes quietly down the long candlelit corridor and of this massive house. She is happy, buoyant, tipsy. GEORGIANA walks towards their bedroom. Suddenly a door op and the YOUNG MAID the DUKE was talking to earlier comes running out, half naked, carrying her clothes in her arms She looks at GEORGIANA in alarm, and runs off. GEORGIANA looks at her, shocked and speechless, as she disappears off into the darkness of the corridor. Georgia turns and proceeds toward the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bedroom the DUKE is sitting half naked on the bed. GEORGIANA stops at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: What is going on?

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: About what? GEORGIANA approaches, unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: What have you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Nothing to concern you. He smiles at her, kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Wait, William. I don’t understand...

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: What is there to understand? GEORGIANA is lost for words.  21 22 23

dialogues.speaker: DUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look very beautiful tonight. Fascinating fabric. Is this dress your design?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Yes it is. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Then allow me to appreciate it in more detail. The DUKE kisses her breasts and proceeds to remove her clothes. GEORGIANA, with a desire to do the right thing, acquiesces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed. Months. The season has changed from summ to autumn, with wind in the trees and leaves on the groun which workmen are busy collecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA and the DUKE sit together in a gigantic dining room at a very long table. In the corner a musician quiet plays the harpsichord providing a low background ambience SERVANTS discreetly serving food and wine. GEORGIANA and the DUKE eat in silence. After a few moments BURLEIGH emerges to whisper something into the ear of the DUKE. He understands the message and nods.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: Send them in... BURLEIGH exits. GEORGIANA looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (Lighting up) Are we having company? Is it Fox? The DUKE chews his food and swallows before he replies.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: Don't you think this mutton has a funny taste?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I do... HEATON enters with a NANNY holding a little three-year-ol girl, CHARLOTTE, by the hand. The girl is very nervous. T DUKE looks at them, then at GEORGIANA.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Charlotte. She will be staying with us. GEORGIANA looks at the little girl who remains absolutely still. Then she looks at the DUKE.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Why...? The DUKE signals to the BUTLER that they can leave the ro upon which the BUTLER leads the NANNY and Charlotte out.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: Because her mother is dead. She has no other place to go. GEORGIANA looks in disbelief at the DUKE. The penny drops

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Have you fathered that child?

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: It's only a little girl, Georgiana, hardly the end of the world. The DUKE sends a suspicious look at the mutton before him looks up again, only to find that GEORGIANA is still star at him. He takes a tiny bite of the mutton, examining its taste as if he suspected poison, during which he continue

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I am pregnant with your child. Surely you are not expecting me to look after her?

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: We have a house full of vacant rooms, G. She need not trouble you. As a matter of fact, she may even be of use; you can practice your motherhood on her... (gesturing at her stomach) ++.until our son arrives. GEORGIANA hands move protectively toward her stomach to reveal she is midway through pregnancy. She looks at him, silently furious and hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This certainly doesn't taste like normal mutton. I am sure something is the matter with it.  24

dialogues.speaker: 24A
dialogues.text: The DUKE pushes his plate away and smiles at her. A SERVA immediately steps forward to take the plate away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA walking past, pauses outside the room in which nanny is putting CHARLOTTE to bed for the night. She hear sobbing coming from inside. GEORGIANA is moved by this bu steals herself against the painful sound and walks off. After a few paces she stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little girl is lying on the bed, the NANNY trying to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Would you leave us, please.

dialogues.speaker: NANNY
dialogues.text: Your Grace, I didn't see you. The NANNY looks nervously at GEORGIANA, not knowing wheth she ought to leave.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: ...leave us, please... The NANNY scurries out of the room. GEORGIANA sits down o CHARLOTTE's bed. CHARLOTTE is hiding her face, still sobb She reaches for her doll, as if it was threatened by GEORGIANA's presence and she means to rescue it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Softly) I am Georgiana. What's your name? CHARLOTTE makes no reply. GEORGIANA smiles at her. She ca see that she is trembling and gently puts her hand on her shoulder to calm her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shh, there now, you are safe here «..SO what do you call your doll? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Surely, it must have a name. Every doll must have a name.  CHARLOTTE stares at her in silence.  25

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let us make a deal, then. Tonight you decide on a name for your doll. You may choose between any in the whole wide world, and then, in the morning, you tell me which one you've picked. Charlotte nods slowly. GEORGIANA rises and turns to leave

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Alice. GEORGIANA turns back to Charlotte and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Good night then Alice. And good night Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's snowing outside and GUESTS arrive in fur coats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSICIANS are playing in the foyer. GEORGIANA - dressed amazingly - receives people with smil and poses as a newspaper sketcher draws her from the corn of the hall. Her belly is gigantic - she is in the very l stage of pregnancy. FOX arrives with the flushed and flas RICHARD SHERIDAN. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN
dialogues.text: An inch more, and I do believe your Grace will explode.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Sheridan certainly knows how to pay a compliment. GEORGIANA smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: There are still a few more weeks to wait.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: A huge belly has never been more becoming on anyone.  26

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN
dialogues.text: And Fox here offers an expert opinion, seeing, as he does, a giant belly every time he passes a mirror. GEORGIANA smiles. SHERIDAN leans against FOX in affected confidentiality.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If your belly were on a woman, we'd all know what to think. FOX leans against SHERIDAN in imitation of his act.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: My dear Sheridan, less than an hour ago, my belly was on a woman - so now what do you think? GEORGIANA delights in the risky repartee.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: That will teach you to insult Mr Fox before the gaming has begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ballroom has been converted into a gaming area with a series of round card tables and is full of GAMBLERS. It h a decadent, opulent and smoky atmosphere. The DUKE is at one table while GEORGIANA sits at another with SHERIDAN to one side and FOX to the other. The conversation runs fast and easy.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Her Grace wins again. GEORGIANA pulls in her chips.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Another wager?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN
dialogues.text: I’m out. My funds have run dry and I’ve no one left to borrow from.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Maybe it would be different if people thought you had the slightest intention of paying them back?  27

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN
dialogues.text: One should never give money to one’s creditors, dear boy. It only encourages them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Is there no one in London not in debt?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN
dialogues.text: Just the poor. They all laugh loudly. Suddenly GEORGIANA stiffens as she feels a sharp pain. She gasps and looks at them in alarm.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Yes... She doesn’t look convinced. Another dart of pain. GEORGIA is in anguish.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would like to... Another shooting pain. By now, FOX, SHERIDAN, and several the other guests have jumped to their feet to help her ou The DUKE notices the turmoil from his table.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Are those labour pains? My wife is in labour! The DUKE now raises his glass and addresses the guests. H looks genuinely excited.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think this calls for a toast. I may have an heir before the night is out. He toasts. EVERYBODY joins in the toast and some cheer, s those who are helping GEORGIANA out of the room. The last image is of the DUKE, happy and proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is quiet. LADY SPENCER hurries inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY SPENCER steps into the room, still dressed in her ca A SERVANT follows her and receives her cape. She is surpr by the sight in front of her: the DUKE is throwing a ball exercise his dogs who scamper around the ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Your Grace —

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: I'm in no mood for conversation, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: But, pray tell, is my daughter -

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: Is your daughter at all able to give me a son? Beat, as LADY SPENCER takes in the situation and quickly contemplates her response.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Take heart, your Grace. As long as the mother is in good health, consider this mishap a draft, a promise of what is soon to come. In our family -

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE
dialogues.text: Yes, yes - LADY SPENCER stops as the DUKE waves her away, in a gestu which roughly signals that the DUKE appreciates her effor to comfort him, but is too troubled to talk. LADY SPENCER smiles politely and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (muttering) Hell and damnation ... The DUKE throws the ball deep into the room, his dogs racing to retrieve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA is sitting by the cot, totally engrossed with h new baby, stroking its arm, staring at its face. A wind u MUSIC BOX is playing nearby. LADY SPENCER enters the room. Georgiana looks up and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite well. LADY SPENCER sends her a warm smile and steps up to look the baby sleeping in GEORGIANA's arms.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: .and is she strong and healthy? GEORGIANA nods and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: She is perfect. LADY SPENCER smiles and looks at the girl.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: She is her mother’s likeness... GEORGIANA smiles as she looks down at the baby with her mother. Then her mind shifts, and her expression becomes darker. There is an edge to her tone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Did William receive you?

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Was he upset that it wasn't a son? He just glanced at her briefly and left. I’ve hardly seen him since.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: It's been a difficult time for His Grace, my dear. Many eyes are upon him, not all of them kind. LADY SPENCER senses the tension and looks back at the bab keen to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why, she's the loveliest... The baby starts to wake up, hungry and crying.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nurse... Lady Spencer gestures to the WET NURSE to come forward which she does, unbuttoning her shirt to feed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Firmly) No, I will do it, thank you. The wet nurse looks to Lady Spencer.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Darling, are you sure...?  30 31 32

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Yes, I am her mother after all. Even if she is only a girl. Georgiana is already starting to feed her hungry baby fro her breast, a picture of earthy motherhood in stark contrast to the pomp of her surroundings. LADY SPENCER looks over at this headstrong young woman, n a little bit worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very wide shot of the empty English countryside, with t train of GILT COACHES mid-frame, glinting in the sunshine TWO MORE COACHES follow, laden with STAFF and LUGGAGE.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. GILT COACHES. DAY
dialogues.text: Close up on the face of a three year old girl, HARRYO, sitting in a GILT COACH. HARRYO sits next to CHARLOTTE, n aged 10, and G (4). GEORGIANA - now four years older - si opposite. She is sketching dress designs while the childr play with cards. In the second COACH the DUKE sits alone and in silence - bar his dogs - staring out of the windows at the passing countryside. A newspaper sits besides him with a story about Georgiana on the front page. He has also aged four years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COACHES go past the Royal Crescent. On the grass in t foreground lots of people are strolling, having picnics, children play.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RENTED BATH HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: THE FIRST COACH stops in front of a MASSIVE VILLA. SERVAN jump down to open the door of the COACH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FOYER alone is fabulous, spacious, sparkling. The DUK surveys the place. Finally he sighs, as if it's a bad mot

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Well. It'll have to do. It's only for a month. The DUKE goes o.s. GEORGIANA enters, accompanied by the children, and soon after by SERVANTS carrying masses of luggage: suitcases, hatboxes, shoeboxes etc. LITTLE G watches them go past.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE G
dialogues.text: If we’re only here for a month, Mama, why do you have so many cases?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (Smiling, ironic) A lady needs a change of clothes, my darling. LITTLE G smile back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, who will get the best bedroom? GEORGIANA looks to her CHILDREN. They run into the house full of excitement and energy, with their mother hot on their heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a massive ball inside, all guests in formal clothes. Leading Whig JAMES HARE addresses the crowd from the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES HARE
dialogues.text: It is always a delight, when one is on holiday, to request a few words of wisdom. So without further ado it is a great honour to hand over to our most distinguished guest... We see the faces of the DUKE and GEORGIANA standing in th darkness of the wings behind HARE. Who is he referring to

dialogues.speaker: JAMES HARE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When she appears, every eye is turned towards her; when absent, she is the subject of universal conversation; and what we see her wearing tonight, I look forward to seeing the rest of you wearing tomorrow... The DUKE’s face seems to sink.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES HARE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...the Empress of Fashion herself ...The Duchess of Devonshire. The CROWD applaud loudly. GEORGIANA enters, accompanied b the DUKE. There’s a hushed ‘wow’ as everyone takes in her extraordinary appearance: she wears a HUGE, THREE FOOT ADORNED WIG with OSTRICH FEATHERS inserted into it. She b at the crowd, the total centre of attention. The DUKE loo uncomfortable next to her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: We come away to Bath to get away from London and all of London has come away to Bath. EVERYONE laughs. The DUKE forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I always appreciate the Honourable Mr Hares' introductions. He has a jeweller's wit; (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: whenever he turns a phrase, one finds another facet.  42 There are chuckles from the CROWD. GEORGIANA, looking confident, strokes the feather in her hair.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And as he suggests, somebody did indeed ask me earlier what kind of feather it is I’m wearing. Well, only two specimens of this rare bird are known to man. One of them has clearly ended up on top of my head. The other, rumour has it, is running for office in the Tory party. There is great laughter. GEORGIANA looks to the side of t room and sees that the DUKE has caught the eye of a young blushing BEAUTY. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATH ASSEMBLY ROOMS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: HIGH TEMPO MUSIC is being played by some MUSICIANS. Many people are dancing energetically on the floor - especiall GEORGIANA who is in the middle of a group of admirers: on high and basking in the attention. GEORGIANA is an expert dancer, moving from one male partn to the next. The CAMERA follows the feather on her head standing high over everyone as she twirls around the room like a sharks fin jutting out above the water line.  43 44 All eyes are upon her: COURT REPORTERS in the corner try sketch it; men look on from the sides with barely disguis sexual interest; women look at her dress, the feather, an then their husbands’ reactions. The DUKE, however, stands at the side, pretending only to be half-watching. GEORGIANA is spurred on by his indifference, and as the dancing progresses, she begins t show off and flirt in inverse proportion to it. GEORGIANA then loses herself in the dancing until...She glances up to see the DUKE talking to another prey - a beautiful young woman in a dark dress, BESS FOSTER. GEORGIANA now sees BESS evidently rejecting the ducal overtures and leaving the room. Rejection is a new experi for the DUKE, and he is appropriately taken aback, as is GEORGIANA. The DUKE's eyes stay on BESS as she leaves int the next room. GEORGIANA stops dancing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (To her partner) Excuse me... GEORGIANA turns and walks away from the DANCERS.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATH ASSEMBLY ROOMS. OCTAGON ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: BESS is helping herself to some food from the sideboard. She is about to take a bite of a tart when she sees GEORGIANA, staring.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I don't believe we have been formally introduced?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: I haven't, at any rate. Lady Elizabeth Foster. They greet each other.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I saw you talking with my husband. GEORGIANA looks at BESS in a levelled way. BESS returns t look.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Yes, he wished to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not usually considered his forte. And you declined?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: I'm ill at ease with male company for the moment. GEORGIANA smiles. BESS smiles back at her. GEORGIANA look at BESS, sizing up this beautiful girl with great interes Beat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: What brings you to Bath? BESS takes a moment to consider how she will answer this.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: My husband, Mr. Foster, is enjoying his mistress in Bournemouth, and I wanted some diversion. And you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (hedges ) The Duke is taking the waters for his gout... Beat. BESS looks as if to say, ‘carry on’.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...and I...for my health. BESS is upset that GEORGIANA has not rewarded her honesty with similar directness.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Really? (imitating gossip) "The Duchess of D., married how- many-years and still no son and heir." GEORGIANA is taken aback, hurt. BESS immediately realises regrets what she’s said.

dialogues.speaker: BESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon. That was an awful thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: But it is the truth, at least. They look at each other. Something passes between them.  GEORGIANA lowers her voice in a conspiratorial way. It’s almost as if they are flirting with each other.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Although I had hoped to avoid being reminded of that. If only for this evening.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Trust me to say something silly. I always do, you know.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Then perhaps you should have accepted the Duke's invitation. You have much in common. BESS does not know if she is allowed to laugh. She looks GEORGIANA and smiles. Then they both laugh. There is a re connection here, two lost people who have found each othe The DUKE enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Well... Home, I think. Georgiana. GEORGIANA and BESS look at him as he leaves. Then GEORGIA gets up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: I've rented some rooms in town.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: We must meet again.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: We must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DUKE’s carriage trundles down the Royal Crescent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DUKE sits on the seat. GEORGIANA, however, has to sit on the floor to make room for the ostrich feather that’s still on top of her head. They are not looking at each other and the strain of thei relationship shows on them both. We remain on GEORGIANA’S face as the bright sounds of young children’s voices fade up until we...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 46
dialogues.text: EXT. BATH PARK — DAY 47 GEORGIANA, a NANNY flanking her, is playing chase and running races with her children in the sunshine. It’s fre and easy and everyone is laughing and having a good time. GEORGIANA steps back to watch the three girls run off and gets her breath back. HARRYO runs and falls. GEORGIANA ru up to comfort her. HARRYO runs off again and GEORGIANA watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: BESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Up and fall down, up and fall down. GEORGIANA turns to see BESS standing behind her.

dialogues.speaker: BESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why can’t we recover like that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Too far to fall now. They smile.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello again.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Hello. [Beat] Your girls are lovely.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Do you have any children?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: I do. Three boys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three boys ... What the Duke wouldn't give for one of them. BESS smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: She looks least like you, your eldest.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Yes. (Makes a decision) I'm sure you know the story. GEORGIANA looks at BESS. BESS does, but she doesn't speak

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My husband's daughter was born before we married. The mother was a maid. The maid died; we took the child.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I shouldn't have spoken.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Never mind. It's the worst kept secret in London. She's nine years old now.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: And...do you love her?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Of course I do. The same as all my children. They are the world to me. BESS smiles, but behind it her own pain shows through.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 49
dialogues.text: 49k INT. BATH. PRIVATE BATHS. DAY - LATER 49k GEORGIANA and BESS come out onto a balcony with tables, benches and chairs. Below and beyond it is a manicured garden with people strolling, pushing wheelchairs etc. It has the feel of an upmarket sanatorium. GEORGIANA walks to a small drinking fountain and stops to sip a cup of hot liquid. BESS takes a sniff and recoils.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Thermal water. It’s the sulphur that makes it smell so bad.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: And you really have to drink it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Twice a day for four weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Do you have any reason to believe you cannot birth a male?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: No. Except four miscarriages, two still births - both of which were sons - and two girls .. BESS feels for her, and smiles supportively. They make their way to a table and sit down. BESS looks around them people are stealing sneaky glances over at GEORGIANA.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Everybody's staring at you... GEORGIANA smiles at her cheekiness. BESS turns right arou to look in the direction of a couple staring at GEORGIANA As she does so GEORGIANA is able to see a DARK BRUISE on BESS’S NECK. GEORGIANA is shocked, and her hand instinctively reaches out to touch her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: What’s that on your neck? BESS is taken off guard. She looks a little vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bess...? BESS looks evenly at Georgiana, as if trying to decide to tell her something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s not illegal for a man to beat his wife with a stick unless the stick is thicker than your thumb. GEORGIANA is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Mr Foster? But - he can't do that...

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Considering what else he's done to me, that's not the worst...  50

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: What could possibly be worse...?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: He's taken my children. He won't let me see them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: What do you propose to do?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Really, I'm at my wits' end. I have made some sort of alliance with a man who will assist me in abducting them. What I'll do when he does, I don't know. Live under an assumed name, I suppose. The law supports Mr. Foster. GEORGIANA is lost in the horror of BESS’s situation.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: And in the meantime, where shall you stay?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Continue lodging I suppose, until my money runs out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Well, there at least, I think I can help. GEORGIANA reaches out to take another drink of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DUKE - continuing the previous scene’s action - picks up a glass and drinks. Georgiana, Bess and the Duke eat. Georgiana and Bess exchange secret glances.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: William? We leave tomorrow. And Lady Elizabeth is not due to meet her parents on the continent for some time. And she hardly visits London at all.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Ah. Pity that.  51 52 53

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: You see she doesn’t have a place to stay.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Oh dear, problem there. BESS and GEORGIANA hold their breath. The DUKE glances up

dialogues.speaker: DUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well why doesn’t she stay with us? For a while at least. Georgiana and Bess grin like schoolgirls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA leads the way down the corridor. BESS follows, gazing at the house, marvelling at the grandiosity of it all. Unlike GEORGIANA’s first arrival it feels informal, free, excited.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: This is incredible ... GEORGIANA, tickled to have BESS with her, takes her arm.  54 55

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (Ironically) Yes. There’s the castle in Ireland, Bolton Abbey, Chiswick, Burlington - and Chatsworth, of course, which is much bigger - but this is more like home. BESS laughs. GEORGIANA leads her through more rooms. GEORGIANA opens a door to reveal a beautiful bedroom with adjacent dressing area. BESS is suitably impressed. They laugh and hug each other close.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am so glad you are here. (Devilish) I have arranged a wonderful start to the season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OPENING NIGHT. A HUGE CRUSH of SOCIAL TYPES are in t theatre. Many of the women have their hair piled high wit an ostrich feather in it. They hold programmes that read ‘School For Scandal’ by Richard Sheridan. JOURNALISTS and CARTOONISTS sit off to the side, like paparazzi, sketching. We see glimpses of their renditions In them, GEORGIANA's large wig looks even larger. ON STAGE the performance is in full flow: an argument between "Sir Peter Teazle" and "Lady Teazle." The actors are made-up and costumed to look suspiciously like GEORGIANA and The DUKE, and the set is a replica in miniature of the Devonshire House living room.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR PLAYING SIR TEAZLE
dialogues.text: “Lady Teazle, Lady Teazle, I’1l not bear it!”

dialogues.speaker: ACTRESS PLAYING LADY TEAZLE
dialogues.text: “Sir Peter, Sir Peter, you may bear it or not as you please; but I ought to have my own way in everything.”

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR PLAYING SIR TEAZLE
dialogues.text: “Lady Teazle, though my life may be made unhappy by your temper, I‘’1l not be ruined by your extravagance.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “My extravagance! I’m sure I am not more extravagant than a woman of fashion ought to be.” IN THEIR BOX the DUKE and GEORGIANA look on, stiff and v separate. BESS sits behind them. There’s a very tense air the DUKE is looking mortified while GEORGIANA seems to kn exactly what’s going on. She looks down at SHERIDAN sitti in the front row, who looks back equally knowingly, and winks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR PLAYING SIR PETER
dialogues.text: “May all the plagues of marriage be doubled on me, if ever I try to be friends with you any more!”

dialogues.speaker: ACTRESS PLAYING LADY TEAZLE
dialogues.text: "So much the better"

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR PLAYING SIR PETER
dialogues.text: "No, no madam.: ‘tis evident you never cared a pin for me, and I was a madman to marry you."

dialogues.speaker: ACTRESS PLAYING LADY TEAZLE
dialogues.text: “And I am sure I was a fool to marry you - an old dangling bachelor... The camera moves into the DUKE. He endures the humiliatio with a straight face but his insides are in knots.

dialogues.speaker: ACTRESS PLAYING LADY TEAZLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-who was single at fifty, only because he never could meet with anyone who could have him.” The audience LAUGH LOUDLY and look up to where the DUKE a GEORGIANA are sitting. The DUKE grips his seat.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR PLAYING SIR TEAZLE
dialogues.text: Very well, madam! Very well! A separate maintenance as soon as you please. Yes, madam, or a divorce!”

dialogues.speaker: ACTRESS PLAYING LADY TEAZLE
dialogues.text: (Triumphant ) “Agreed! Agreed!” The audience laugh and cheer. Amid the noise, GEORGIANA looks across the theatre to see the reaction. She sees a handsome YOUNG MAN in his 20s. S looks back to the stage, but the YOUNG MAN remains gazing at her. She looks back, realising who it is - CHARLES GRE Unlike the crowd, he is not laughing at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the show: close up on champagne cork popping and champagne poured into glasses. The DUKE is skulking aroun the edge of the crowd. GEORGIANA and BESS meet with FOX. 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess. This is Mr. Fox. The Leader of the Opposition. Mr Fox, Lady Elizabeth Foster. BESS is impressed. They nod at each other. CHARLES GREY approaches from behind FOX.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Ah. And here is my protegee, Charles Grey. BESS nods to both the men

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Mr Grey.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: He’s our newest bright young man - scarcely out of Cambridge and already a member of Parliament. GEORGIANA can’t take her eyes off him. He looks at her to BESS notices this and quickly starts a conversation with FOX, leaving GEORGIANA to talk to GREY alone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I always felt you would do well, Mr Grey.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Did you enjoy the play? GREY is uneasy, but still looks GEORGIANA straight in the eye as he replies.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I must confess I did not entirely. GEORGIANA is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I hope you haven’t lost your sense of humour since entering politics...

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Not that I am aware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you do realise ‘School For Scandal’ is written as a comedy?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Yes...although from where I sat it read as a tragedy. GEORGIANA is troubled. GREY’s unexpected comments affect her deeply. Just then SHERIDAN approaches with open arms.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN
dialogues.text: Your Grace! How we've missed you! In your absence London has been reduced to the dreariest province! GEORGIANA smiles. She breaks her eyes from GREY'S and sha resumes her usually effortless social persona.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: And this, of course, is the playwright, Mr. Sheridan. May I present the Lady Elizabeth. SHERIDAN greets BESS. Then, with an apologetic mien at th others, he pulls GEORGIANA away.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN
dialogues.text: Pardon us. I do not mean to be rude, but I have an entire cast dying to meet the Duchess. I shall return her in a moment, promise. SHERIDAN and GEORGIANA leave. BESS watches GREY as GREY watches them go. She looks to the DUKE, who has found som consolation in the form of a gauche young GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA throws a look back to GREY, then SHERIDAN presents her to a lined-up CAST, who all curtsy and bow.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Were we fair on the Duke?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN
dialogues.text: It could have been worse. (Whispers to her) My original title was "The Bad Marriage." SHERIDAN smiles. GEORGIANA does not. A SERVANT enters with a tray of drinks. Everybody helps themselves to one. SHERIDAN produces a bottle of opium.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Opium?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Just a drop... SHERIDAN pours opium in their drinks. A few of the actors actresses have a drop too. GREY takes this in as he watches the DUKE and then GEORGIANA. GEORGIANA turns and looks at him. For an extra beat.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DEVONSHIRE HOUSE. GEORGIANA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 58 BESS and GEORGIANA are in nightclothes, sprawled across each other on the bed. They are intimate and relaxed, lik two teenage girls after a night’s clubbing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Were you at all able to forget things and enjoy yourself?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: It was a wonderful distraction, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: I talked all night to Mister Grey...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Oh yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in love with you. GEORGIANA laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: My dear Bess. No he’s not. In fact I fear the very opposite. GEORGIANA looks at her, thinks. BESS smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Can't you tell by the way he looks at you? Honestly, can't you tell?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Stop it, please.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Georgiana. Procreation is not just about offspring. In fact, it can be quite nice.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (laughs uncertainly, lies) Yes, I know...

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Try to close your eyes ... and envision Grey slowly opening your dress ... and kissing your back. GEORGIANA starts to giggle.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Oh, please, they never do such things...

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Oh yes they do. BESS gets up and lies behind GEORGIANA. GEORGIANA looks a little nervous about this.

dialogues.speaker: BESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Close your eyes...Grey is behind you....slowly opening your dress... BESS pulls back part of GEORGIANA’s clothing to reveal he shoulder. BESS begins to kiss it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Bess, stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Firmly) ...close your eyes....kissing your back... GEORGIANA relents and closes her eyes. BESS continues to kiss her back. Suddenly GEORGIANA goes silent, a look of real surprise on her face: she is experiencing sensations she never knew even existed. Bess continues, soft but in charge, as they both allow themselves to become lost in the erotically charged momen GEORGIANA lets out little gasps of pleasure... BESS pushes it further... Her hands explore under GEORGIANA’S nightclothes... Over her breasts... The tops of her legs... GEORGIANA gasps again, a realisation that parts of her bo could give such pleasure... BESS tugs GEORGIANA’S hair back a little... Her hands reach further... GEORGIANA closes her eyes...

dialogues.speaker: BESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Whispers) There...see... BESS stops what she’s doing. Beat. They both breathe heavily, the sexual tension and arousal hanging heavy in the air. They are a little embarrassed, scared even of wh might happen if they carried on, and for a moment it seem that is what they might well do... But BESS gets up and walks to the window as GEORGIANA readjusts her clothes. They regain composure and try to carry on as if nothing has really happened.

dialogues.speaker: BESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the play this evening, there was a scene in which Lady Teazle and Mr. Surface discuss their affair. They acknowledge that once a lady of quality has provided her husband with a son then she may take a lover. GEORGIANA takes it in.  59 60 61

dialogues.speaker: BESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be ready, dear G, when the time comes. GEORGIANA lies back on the bed, eyes wide open, thinking. This image is held as the sound of a haunting operatic voice - accompanied by harpsichord - starts over it and carries us into the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the grounds of a huge country house and its estate. SWARMS of COUNTRY PEOPLE, MEN on HORSES and TENAN are present, with others arriving all the time. Massive amounts of food are laid out on trestle tables with a ten for the gentry on the other side. The singing and harpsichord continue, and we find that AN OPERA singer and HARPSICHORD perform to a grand outdoor picnic. We see the DUKE and BESS standing together. FOX and GREY at the rear of the audience, looking on. GEORGIANA is with her children, working her way through t ORDINARY PEOPLE and TENANTS, making them feel welcome. Th respond with reverence. She walks up to LADY SPENCER and embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Hello Mama.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: (Coolly) Hello my dear. BESS comes over too.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: We’re so glad you were able to visit, Lady Spencer.  LADY SPENCER looks hurt.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Are ‘we’ really?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Yes, G speaks of you all the time.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: Well that is nice to hear. My daughter’s letters have become so short of late that finally they do not exist at all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I do apologise Mama. It is merely a reflection of my current state of happiness...

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: (Cutting across) I only know what she is up to by reading the Morning Post. GEORGIANA is stung by this. The DUKE wanders up behind, surveying the scene.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And how long do you intend to stay on Lady Elizabeth?

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Please, ‘Bess’. I don’t know. I’m sure I’ve worn out my welcome already.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Lady Elizabeth is free to stay with us for as long as she likes. LADY SPENCER is left open-mouthed, a little alarmed at ho close they all seem. The music has stopped and everyone turn and politely applaud the musicians. FOX and some WHI come forward. GEORGIANA turns and smiles broadly at them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Who let these radicals through the gates of Chatsworth?  62

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: No one lets us in anywhere! That's why we’re radicals!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FORMAL GARDENS. DAY
dialogues.text: The DUKE performs his duty talking with the important people in the tent: other aristocrats, politicians and wealthy businessmen. FOX, SHERIDAN and GREY are here too. GEORGIANA is opposite, amongst the ORDINARY PEOPLE, where she is carrying food to their tables and making sure they are being well looked after.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What a fine spread. GEORGIANA turns to see GREY behind her, coming over from the tent.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Thank you. We do our best. GEORGIANA starts to walk through the tables with a plate food. He follows.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: We? From what I hear you run these open days single-handedly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Well, the Duke does find inviting all and sundry to the house a little... testing. But it’s only once a week.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: The Duke would prefer his tenants to starve?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: It is his property.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Then he must surely embrace the responsibilities that come with it. Or perhaps His Grace would prefer instead to be divested of such troublesome possessions.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (Provocatively) What an interesting idea.  63 GREY, encouraged by her double meaning, continues.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: You know, I despise the fact that so few men can have such precious things - and that they mismanage them so appallingly. GEORGIANA smiles at him. She knows he is talking about he

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: And what would you suggest? He returns her smile, remembering the exchange from years ago.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: That people should be set free.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: And will freedom alone make them happy?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: The point is not to make people happy. The point is to make them free, so they can pursue their own idea of happiness...whatever that may be. GEORGIANA looks impressed. She realizes how close they're standing, and in full view of the PEOPLE. She moves away few feet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I must get another plate.. GEORGIANA walks off. GREY watches her go, happy in the knowledge he has made an impact. He starts back toward FO and SHERIDAN.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHATSWORTH. FORMAL GARDENS. DAY
dialogues.text: It is toward the end of the day. The sun is casting long shadows on the lawn as the picnic is being packed up. GEORGIANA leans against a low wall, sipping a cordial, al the while watching GREY in conversation with some men. BE approaches GEORGIANA.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Whatever is the matter with you? Your behaviour is so out of the ordinary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel like keeping to myself today... BESS sits down beside her, leaning close and intimate. Th look at the men, GREY at the centre, then look at each other. BESS smiles broadly. GEORGIANA blushes.  64 BESS digs GEORGIANA playfully and gently in the ribs. The giggle like schoolgirls. GEORGIANA looks up to see LADY SPENCER is watching, a disapproving expression on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY SPENCER and GEORGIANA are walking through. Other GUESTS mill around.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: (Hushed) But you have only known her three months!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Bess is my friend! She is the very best of women.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: She seems to be many things, but I would be hard pushed to say she were that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: It may pain you to recognise it Mama, but a great change has come over my life and its name is Lady Elizabeth Foster...about whom it can be truly said I have at long last found my other self. LADY SPENCER’s pulse races. She wants to interject.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I understand if that may make you feel a little jealous. LADY SPENCER stops.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SPENCER
dialogues.text: (Fierce whisper) This is a dangerous path to choose my girl.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I am not a girl, mother, I am the Duchess of Devonshire. It would serve you well to remember that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and you have begun to cavort so constantly in public you cannot live for your own soul. It is no surprise you are gathering weeds instead of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 66 GEORGIANA is stunned, like a little girl cut dead by her mother for showing off. LADY SPENCER turns on her heels a walks off leaving GEORGIANA fuming inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA, a rebellious look on her face, takes a drink from a BUTLER. She then heads toward GREY who is among a group of MEN. As he sees GEORGIANA he excuses himself fro the conversation and meets her.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Your Grace...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Mr Grey, I have been thinking. The national election is in six weeks, yes? How is the campaign going?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Terribly. Our only hope is to save Westminster for Fox. GEORGIANA smiles. There’s a mischievous sparkle in her ey

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: I have many faults as you well know, not least among them is my ability to draw attention. Perhaps we could use that to our advantage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA stands on a platform dressed in the most outrageous costume yet, her hair piled three foot high above her head and decorated with Whig-coloured ribbons. In front is a HUGE CROWD noisy: a massive mix of people from drunks and prostitutes to lords and ladies. Banners proclaim WHIGS, VOTE FOX. JOURNALISTS mill around, scribbling into notebooks and sketching GEORGIANA. In the crowd, women are fanning themselves with fans bearing Georgiana’s likeness. It’s like a pop concert.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (Shouts to the crowd) Ladies and Gentlemen. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give you a man who will inform us of the work we must do and the party we so believe in! Mister Charles Grey! APPLAUSE as GREY moves to take the stage. GEORGIANA and GREY exchange a look as he positions himself.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I am here in Westminster to speak on behalf of our candidate Sir Charles James Fox... APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I wish only to address a single issue. Power. GEORGIANA looks at GREY, clearly proud of him.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The basis of power in our country is land, as it has been for centuries. And the aristocracy owns nearly all of it... There are a few laughs from the CROWD.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -.-along with all the places in the Government, control of the House of Commons, Ambassadors, Governors, Judges, and a host of other posts too numerous to mention. They maintain this influence by transferring their land intact, generation after generation. And in so doing continue to dominate English life. GREY stops to look at the faces of the PUBLIC looking bac at him. They are with him.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, if we win this election, if we get the power we seek, what will we do with it? GREY’s listeners are quiet. GREY proceeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will we merely follow in the footsteps of those that came before us? Master the art of compromise? Of postponing the greater good for the greater advantage? Will we do that? (Long pause) No. We won’t. Because we believe in the words we've spoken... A few scattered ‘hear hears’ begin.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +..and we have faith in the hearts we've stirred. More ‘HEAR HEARS’. GREY’s rhetoric takes flight.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The world is on the brink of disaster or salvation. From France to America, men and women are struggling to free themselves and find meaning in their existence. Change is upon us. Loud calls of ‘YES’ and applause.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We shall not return to the old ways! We shall not shirk our promises and our duties! We shall take England into this brave new world and shake the thunder from the skies! This we vow! APPLAUSE. CHEERS. GEORGIANA gazes at GREY. GREY looks at her, flushed and excited. She blushes like mad.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. COVENT GARDEN HUSTINGS. BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: GREY stands alone. GEORGIANA approaches.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: How did I do?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (Trying to hide her feelings) I think it was not an embarrassment.  Grey's face crumbles in disappointment. GEORGIANA grins.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was a marvel. GREY smiles. A big open, boyish smile of relief.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: But did you agree with what I said?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Every word. GREY gains self-confidence. He approaches GEORGIANA.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I was nervous. Your presence trebled the numbers at least. GREY is now very close indeed. GEORGIANA feels the effect of it. She becomes short of breath. GREY speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am nervous even now... GEORGIANA knows that she ought to keep a distance, but remains where she is.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: So am I. There is tension in the air. A POLITICIAN walks past them They both acknowledge him as he goes. Then GEORGIANA star at GREY, and moves a little closer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think of me when we are not together?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: (surprised) You ought to know I do... of you more than anything else.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: You hesitated before replying ...

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I am unused to being asked so directly, and by you of all people. GREY walks close. He very gently puts his hand on hers. S looks down at his hand, then up at him, blushing a little  68 69 70 71 72 73 74 75

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering) I think of you every day. They look lovingly at one another. GEORGIANA is just abou to reward GREY's candour with a confession of her feeling when the sight of SERVANT approaching brings her to remember herself. She withdraws her hand.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: Your carriage awaits Your Grace. GREY nods. GEORGIANA starts to leave, her eyes remaining Grey until she turns a corner and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA enters. Silence. She races across, the soles of shoes echoing as she click-clacks across the vast space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA makes her way quickly down the hall, her shoes still making that distinctive sound.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: (Hushed whisper) Bess. As she approaches the door to BESS's room her pace slows two servants are listening outside it. GEORGIANA is perplexed. When they see her they stand back looking awkward. GEORGIANA continues walking toward them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing outside Lady Elizabeth’s bedroom?  The servants don’t reply. GEORGIANA comes closer, then finally stops. Suddenly the noise of her shoes clicking on the floor is replaced by t muffled noise of BESS and the DUKE having sex: passionate energetic, enjoyable. For several painful, humiliating and shocked moments GEORGIANA is paralyzed in front of the servants. Then GEORGIANA backs away down the hall and is off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA’S hat sits on a table, the ‘VOTE FOX’ sign clea visible on its side. GEORGIANA’S hand hangs down over a chair. THE DOOR opens and the DUKE enters, stealthily. The sun i just pouring GRAY LIGHT into the room. He closes the door very softly and then turns to see... GEORGIANA sitting on his bed. She looks ashen. They stare each other.

dialogues.speaker: THE SAME. 5 MINUTES LATER. 77
dialogues.text: GEORGIANA paces. The DUKE sits on the bed, caught. It is difficult to see if he is actually ashamed, but he is listening patiently to GEORGIANA.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIANA
dialogues.text: Of all the women in England, you had to throw yourself upon her. I have not objected once to any of your affairs, I have accepted whatever arrangement you have proposed, I have raised Charlotte as my own daughter, but this... I have one single thing of my own... why couldn't you let me keep Elizabeth for myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a worried BESS coming up the corridor outside GEORGIANA’s bedroom to find out what all the noise is abo
